quote: GreyConE outperforms state-of-the-art Greybox fuzzer (AFL [7]) and concolic test generation (S2E [10]) in terms of branch coverage achieved and runtime for many of the benchmark SystemC designs.
Exhaustive testing of high-level designs pose an arduous challenge due to complex branching conditions, loop structures and inherent concurrency of hardware designs.
Test engineers aim to generate quality test-cases satisfying various code coverage metrics to ensure minimal presence of bugs in a design.
We developed GreyConE by interleaving greybox fuzzing and concolic execution.
A test-case is “interesting”, if it covers a previously unexplored basic block, or covers it for a unique number of times.
One major drawback of symbolic execution is treating all program inputs as symbolic variables.
Symbolic execution is a formal technique for generating quality test-cases.
We evaluate the efﬁcacy of GreyConE in two aspects: (a) coverage improvement and (b) run-time speedup and compare our results with state-of-the-art testing techniques.
For every design, GreyConE achieves maximum possible coverage post one call to concolic engine.
GreyConE needs fewer test-cases than both AFL and S2E indicating good quality test-case generation.
